text_value: Name: The Operative Painters and Decorators' Union of Australia. Victorian branch.
Address: Box 46, Trades Hall, Carlton South, 3053.

General Note: This valuable collection of records provides fresh information about one of Victoria's earliest craft unions, the Operative Painters & Decorators, during the period 1886 to 1971. It contains a wide range of material, including Minute Books(1886-1937); rule books; correspondence ( inward/ outward); awards and determinations, pamphlets, circulars, mewspaper cuttings, journals reports and other printed material. The pre-1900 records uncover new facts about the Painters' involvement with the Political Labour League, which preceded the Victorian Labor Party, Tom Mann, the I.W.W. and the 1890s depression. There is interesting information, too, about the union's long history of support for pacifism- from its involvement in the 1916 anti-conscription campaign to the 1930 Anti-War Committee and, more recently, Painters' support for the 1966-7 Seamen's Union ban on ships carrying war supplies to Vietnam.

The collection is strongest in the area of union industrial activity, such as the formation and operation of a Painters Wages Board from 1910, when the union was first registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act; union officials' involvement in arbitration and workers' compensation, and their concern about painting artisans' conditions in the Public Works Department and on Housing Commission projects.
The records are divided into 12 groups as follows:
Building Workers Social and Political Picnic Committee.
This collection of bound volumes, which are in excellent condition, contains useful information about the early history, rules and industrial and political policy of the union from 1886 to 1937.
Minute Book. United Society of Painters and Decorators. Vol.1. Contains material on the 1890s. depression and early support for labor candidates.
Ditto. Vol.2. More re Political Labor Council proposals for a daily labor newspaper, the formation of the first Federal Labor Party, wom- en's suffrage, Tom Mann, May Day.

Minute Book. The Painters, Paperhangers and Decorators Society of Victoria. Vol.1. Contains material on the I.W.W. The Labor Call news- paper, amalgamation of painting unions, affiliat- ion with the Political Labor Council and on the Building Trades Council.

Ditto. Vol.2. Indexed material. Re anti-conscript- ion campaign from 1916, financial support for the A.L.P. agitation for a 40 hour week, the "Red Flag" hoisted on the Melb. T.H.C. in 1918, campaign for One Big Union, the War Services Home Commission.
Ditto. Vol.3. Re health risks in the painting trade, more about the 40 hour week campaign.
Ditto. Vol.4. Re Apprenticeship Commission, the Industrial Printing Co., unemployment.

Ditto. Vol.5. One Big Union, the A.C.T.U. the Anti-War Committee , relations between the Painters and the T.H.C. in 1936, the fund for Spanish workers, more about The Labor Call and the 40 hour week campaign.
Federal, Branch and Sub-Branch Rules. The Federated House and Ship Painters, Paperhangers, and Decorators' Employees' Association of Australia. 57 pp. 2 copies.
